channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: He drove more than 600 miles for a haircut. He's not alone
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: People from across and outside California have been driving hours to visit salons in Sutter and Yuba counties, open despite stay-at-home order.
item.content:encoded: People from across and outside California have been driving hours to visit salons in Sutter and Yuba counties, open despite stay-at-home order.

media:content.media:description: Wes Heryford, 42, owner of the Butte House Barber Shop in Yuba City, with J. Farr, 28, a customer who drove more than 10 hours from Olympia, Washington State for a haircut. Photo courtesy of Wes Heryford
media:content.media:credit: Photo courtesy of Wes Heryford/Photo courtesy of Wes Heryford

item.title: L.A. County health officials warn against drive-in graduation celebrations
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: As students graduate in Los Angeles County, public health officials are warning against marking the milestone with drive-in celebrations.
item.content:encoded: As students graduate in Los Angeles County, public health officials are warning against marking the milestone with drive-in celebrations.

media:content.media:description: The staff and faculty of Cal State San Marcos celebrated the Class of 2020 with a parade on Friday, May 15, 2020 in San Marcos, California. Graduates and their families remained in their cars and received their diploma covers. Due to COVID-19 the graduation commencement has been postponed indefinitely.
media:content.media:credit: Jarrod Valliere/Jarrod Valliere/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Person with coronavirus attends Mother's Day church service, exposes 180 in Butte County
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Almost 200 at Mother's Day church service were exposed to the coronavirus by an attendee with COVID-19, officials say.
item.content:encoded: Almost 200 at Mother's Day church service were exposed to the coronavirus by an attendee with COVID-19, officials say.

media:content.media:description: This transmission electron microscope image shows SARS-CoV-2, also known as 2019-nCoV, the coronavirus virus that causes COVID-19
media:content.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Rocky Mountain Laboratories

item.title: California continues to ease into reopening amid coronavirus fight
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Kevin Baxter, Christopher Goffard
item.description: More hiking trails and recreation areas reopened Saturday as California continued to ease into the recovery phase of its fight against the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: More hiking trails and recreation areas reopened Saturday as California continued to ease into the recovery phase of its fight against the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - MAY 15: People take advantage of the newly opened walking path on the Strand in Manhattan Beach, CA, Friday, May 15, 2020, during the coronavirus pandemic. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. City Council approves plans to turn developer fees into emergency arts grants
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: Los Angeles' COVID-19 arts relief program will dispense grants to artists, small arts organizations and theaters at "the greatest risk of hardship."
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles' COVID-19 arts relief program will dispense grants to artists, small arts organizations and theaters at "the greatest risk of hardship."

media:content.media:description: BRIGHT LIGHTS: The NoHo Arts Center on Magnolia Boulevard is one of the many theaters that have become part of a flourishing arts district in North Hollywood.

item.title: Magnitude 3.3 earthquake reported near Hollister, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported Saturday morning at 9:38 a.m. Pacific time 10 miles from Hollister, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported Saturday morning at 9:38 a.m. Pacific time 10 miles from Hollister, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: LAPD wants to give rapid-result coronavirus tests to everyone it arrests
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A coronavirus test with results within 15 minutes could prevent the virus' spread and the LAPD is pushing city officials to get the equipment.
item.content:encoded: A coronavirus test with results within 15 minutes could prevent the virus' spread and the LAPD is pushing city officials to get the equipment.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 29: Officer Nick Ferara checks the address for his next food donation drop with other officers at LAPD Harbor station in San Pedro on Wednesday, April 29, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Community members nominated other community members to be recipients of 150 free food bags and much of the food was also donated or reduced in price for the officers. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Some California gyms reopen in defiance of stay-at-home rules
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Phil Diehl
item.description: Some California gyms reopen in defiance of stay-at-home rules
item.content:encoded: Some California gyms reopen in defiance of stay-at-home rules

media:content.media:description: Lou Uridel, owner of the MetroFlex Gym in Oceanside, spoke at the protest rally where over 100 people turned out for the event at the gym on Wednesday. Uridel was arrested and cited on Sunday after refusing to close and has since been released. N photo by Don Boomer

item.title: About half of all small businesses in danger of failing during pandemic, survey finds
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: If the pandemic-induced economic turmoil lasts past Memorial Day, about half of U.S. small businesses could be in danger of failing, survey finds.
item.content:encoded: If the pandemic-induced economic turmoil lasts past Memorial Day, about half of U.S. small businesses could be in danger of failing, survey finds.

media:content.media:description: Celene Navarrete (L) and Chiara Arroyo in front of the LA libreria Bookstore. The bookstore is closed. THIS IS FOR A STORY BY KEVIN BAXTER ON TWO BUSINESSES.

item.title: Phase 2 of reopening California | Striking photos from around the state
item.dc:creator: Times Staff
item.description: Visual look at the second phase to reopen California amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Visual look at the second phase to reopen California amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 11: The flight crew for a Hainan Airlines flight walk through the Tom Bradley International Terminal, Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) which is now requiring travelers to wear face covering to help keep fellow passengers and crew safe by limiting the spread of the coronavirus Covid-19. The new requirements for wearing face masks in Los Angels began Monday at LAX and on local public transit. LAX on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County has more open this weekend than it has in months. What you can and can't do
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Hannah Fry, Luke Money
item.description: Southern California is reopening but there are still strict safety rules aimed at slowing the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Southern California is reopening but there are still strict safety rules aimed at slowing the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - MAY 15: Following a walk on the beach, a couple walk toward the newly opened walking path on the Strand in Manhattan Beach, CA, Friday, May 15, 2020, during the coronavirus pandemic. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: The coronavirus outbreak could be the textbook for virtual school
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: In this time of virtual classes, the pandemic itself could be the textbook for students.
item.content:encoded: In this time of virtual classes, the pandemic itself could be the textbook for students.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 13: Mira Kwon, 16, a junior at Marlborough School, who is active at the local level with Zoomers to Boomers, shops for a client at Monsieur Marcel Gourmet Market at the Original Farmers Market on Wednesday, May 13, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. Zoomers to Boomers delivers groceries (NO DELIVERY FEE) to our elderly and immunocompromised community members so they can shelter in place due to the coronavirus. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Wondering if L.A.'s new mask rules are overkill? Look at the Hong Kong example
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Virtually the entire population of Hong Kong wore masks voluntarily from the beginning. They have had four COVID deaths.
item.content:encoded: Virtually the entire population of Hong Kong wore masks voluntarily from the beginning. They have had four COVID deaths.

media:content.media:description: Mandatory Credit: Photo by JEROME FAVRE/EPA-EFE/REX (10550487f) People line up to receive free face masks from a convenient store chain in Hong Kong, China, 07 January 2020. People over 65 years of age were given 5 face masks each. Hong Kongers have been lining up outside supermarkets, drugstores and pharmacies daily to buy toilet paper, tissues, bleach and face masks since the beginning of the coronavirus, which originated in the Chinese city of Wuhan and has so far killed at least 638 people, infecting over 31,000 others, mostly in China. Mask giveaway in Hong Kong amid coronavirus outbreak, China - 07 Feb 2020 ** Usable by LA, CT and MoD ONLY **

item.title: Even vigilant Angelenos are fed up with distancing and are bending the rules
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry, Sonja Sharp
item.description: Coronavirus: Some Angelenos loosen up their personal boundaries as they try to balance safety and mental health
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: Some Angelenos loosen up their personal boundaries as they try to balance safety and mental health

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - MAY 13: From Left - Charlotte Cooper, Abby Hercules and Gaby Cutini all of Los Angeles celebrate Hercules' birthday at Ocean View Park in Santa Monica during the coronavirus pandemic on Wednesday, May 13, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. This group of friends have found it hard to socialize in person during the coronavirus pandemic. Now that the beach is reopened they thought Hercules' birthday was a great reason to reconnect. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Rural California is reopening despite little coronavirus testing. Is it too soon?
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Sean Greene, Matt Stiles
item.description: Twenty California counties have re-opened, but according to a Times analysis, testing to date remains low in many rural parts of the state. One challenge: Some residents don't want it.
item.content:encoded: Twenty California counties have re-opened, but according to a Times analysis, testing to date remains low in many rural parts of the state. One challenge: Some residents don't want it.

media:content.media:description: MARYSVILLE, CA -- MAY 06: Lanie Gil, server, cleans the table where guests recently had lunch at Courthouse Cafe on Wednesday, May 6, 2020, in Marysville, CA. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County looks at whether some cities could reopen sooner than others
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Luke Money, Patrick McGreevy
item.description: L.A. County remains the epicenter of the novel coronavirus in the state, with more than 1,700 deaths and more than 35,000 confirmed cases.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County remains the epicenter of the novel coronavirus in the state, with more than 1,700 deaths and more than 35,000 confirmed cases.

media:content.media:description: Carlos Marroquin, 53, owner of Planet Soccer, practices social distancing while talking to customer, Benton Watkins, 13, of Santa Clarita, as he tries on a new pair of soccer cleats inside the recently reopened Newhall store. Both are wearing protective face masks.

item.title: You cured a deadly disease — and now you're afflicted by fame
item.dc:creator: Daniel Miller
item.description: Jonas Salk was hailed a hero for helping to defeat polio. But fame came at a cost. Will the same befall creators of a coronavirus vaccine?
item.content:encoded: Jonas Salk was hailed a hero for helping to defeat polio. But fame came at a cost. Will the same befall creators of a coronavirus vaccine?

media:content.media:description: Dr Jonas Salk gives an eight year old boy a trial polio vaccine at the Frick Elementary School, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, February, 1954. (Photo by Underwood Archives/Getty Images)

item.title: Atmospheric river will focus rain on Northern and Central California
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: An upper-level low-pressure system from the North Pacific will tap into subtropical moisture, bringing rain to California.
item.content:encoded: An upper-level low-pressure system from the North Pacific will tap into subtropical moisture, bringing rain to California.

media:content.media:description: A deep low-pressure system in the Pacific promises late-season rain for Northern California.
media:content.media:credit: NASA GOES-West satellite & Los Angeles Times

item.title: Earthquake: 3.1 quake shakes near Clovis, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.1 earthquake was reported at 7:53 p.m. Friday, 119 miles from Clovis, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.1 earthquake was reported at 7:53 p.m. Friday, 119 miles from Clovis, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: Blunt force trauma listed as cause of death for Kobe Bryant, others in helicopter crash
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The Los Angeles County coroner autopsy report says blunt force trauma was cause of death in the crash that killed Kobe Bryant. No illegal substances or alcohol were found in the bloodstream of pilot Ara Zobayan.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles County coroner autopsy report says blunt force trauma was cause of death in the crash that killed Kobe Bryant. No illegal substances or alcohol were found in the bloodstream of pilot Ara Zobayan.

media:content.media:description: In this image taken Monday, Jan. 27, 2020, and provided by the National Transportation Safety Board, NTSB investigator Carol Hogan examines wreckage as part of the NTSB's investigation of a helicopter crash near Calabasas, Calif. The Sunday, Jan. 26 crash killed former NBA basketball player Kobe Bryant, his 13-year-old daughter, Gianna, and seven others (James Anderson/National Transportation Safety Board via AP)

item.title: Newsom urges California tribal casinos to reconsider opening, citing coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom appealed to a group of Native American tribes to reconsider plans to reopen their casinos in the coming days, warning that the coronavirus poses a continuing threat.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom appealed to a group of Native American tribes to reconsider plans to reopen their casinos in the coming days, warning that the coronavirus poses a continuing threat.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Jerry Brown cleared the way for a new tribal casino to be built near the Central Valley city of Madera

item.title: Earthquake: 3.4 quake strikes near Ridgecrest, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: The earthquake occurred 58 miles from Porterville, 61 miles from California City, 63 miles from Lindsay and 67 miles from Exeter.
item.content:encoded: The earthquake occurred 58 miles from Porterville, 61 miles from California City, 63 miles from Lindsay and 67 miles from Exeter.

item.title: State strips medical license of UCLA doctor accused of sexually assaulting another physician
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: The Medical Board of California moved Thursday to strip the license of Dr. Guillermo Andres Cortes, adopting the recommendation of an administrative law judge who heard days of testimony late last year about sexual misconduct allegations.
item.content:encoded: The Medical Board of California moved Thursday to strip the license of Dr. Guillermo Andres Cortes, adopting the recommendation of an administrative law judge who heard days of testimony late last year about sexual misconduct allegations.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA NOVEMBER 21, 2017 -- Meena Zareh, a doctor at USC Keck, says she was sexually assaulted by a supervising doctor while at work. She has filed a civil lawsuit against USC, its multimillion-dollar medical practice, Keck Medicine, and L.A. County, saying she was harassed and retaliated for sounding the alarm about the assault. Zareh is now a cardiology fellow at USC Keck. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ralphs offers one-time 'thank you' bonus after union protests end of coronavirus pay raise
item.dc:creator: Suhauna Hussain
item.description: Ralphs employees and union workers gathered outside a store in Los Angeles on Friday to protest the company's decision to end a coronavirus-related pay raise. Shortly after the protest, Kroger, which owns Ralphs, announced it would award one-time bonuses.
item.content:encoded: Ralphs employees and union workers gathered outside a store in Los Angeles on Friday to protest the company's decision to end a coronavirus-related pay raise. Shortly after the protest, Kroger, which owns Ralphs, announced it would award one-time bonuses.

media:content.media:description: Kroger, owner of Ralphs and other chains, announced a hiring spree Friday.

item.title: Sheriff watchdog seeking subpoena for documents in alleged Kobe Bryant crash photo cover-up
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Los Angeles County's chief law enforcement watchdog is seeking to subpoena documents related to allegations that Sheriff Alex Villanueva directed a cover up after deputies shared graphic photos of the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, his daughter and seven others.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County's chief law enforcement watchdog is seeking to subpoena documents related to allegations that Sheriff Alex Villanueva directed a cover up after deputies shared graphic photos of the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, his daughter and seven others.

media:content.media:description: Lakers star Kobe Bryant warms up before a game against the New Orleans Pelicans on Jan. 21.

item.title: Man killed by LAPD officers had threatened sister, shot a door, police say
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A man killed by Los Angeles police in the Harbor Gateway area on Thursday had fired a bullet into a door in his family's home and threatened his sister before officers arrived, according to the LAPD.
item.content:encoded: A man killed by Los Angeles police in the Harbor Gateway area on Thursday had fired a bullet into a door in his family's home and threatened his sister before officers arrived, according to the LAPD.

item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.2 earthquake was reported Friday at 2:47 p.m., 30 miles from Susanville, Calif., according to the U.S.

item.title: Orange County's coronavirus spike continues as case count passes 4,000
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The latest increase in COVID-19 cases in Orange County continues a multiday trend even as officials push to lift coronavirus restrictions.
item.content:encoded: The latest increase in COVID-19 cases in Orange County continues a multiday trend even as officials push to lift coronavirus restrictions.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- MONDAY, MAY 11, 2020: Beach-goers relax on the beach, despite Gov. Newsom's active-use-only allowance at the beach in Huntington Beach, CA, on May 11, 2020. The city of Huntington Beach is still pursuing their lawsuit against the state to reopen the beach to all forms of activities - including sun bathing.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. Councilman Huizar, embroiled in FBI probe, faces calls from colleagues to step down
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Dakota Smith, David Zahniser
item.description: Jose Huizar said he will 'limit my participation' on the L.A. City Council to avoid being a 'distraction.' But the details are still being worked out, he said.
item.content:encoded: Jose Huizar said he will 'limit my participation' on the L.A. City Council to avoid being a 'distraction.' But the details are still being worked out, he said.

Newsom's active-use-only allowance at the beach in Huntington Beach, CA, on May 11, 2020. item.title: USC's first-ever online graduation: Surreal pomp, unprecedented circumstances
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: USC is famous for its colorful graduation ceremonies, but in the year of coronavirus, the university conferred almost 20,000 degrees over Zoom.
item.content:encoded: USC is famous for its colorful graduation ceremonies, but in the year of coronavirus, the university conferred almost 20,000 degrees over Zoom.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE, CA - MAY 15: Maria Morales, a member of the USC Class of 2020 watches a laptop with Zoom meeting during her virtual graduation via Zoom with her brother Manny Morales, left, mother Pilar Morales and stepdad Victor Ramos, right, on Friday, May 15, 2020 in Orange, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Live video feed helps spot wildfires in Southern California
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: Stuck at home because of the coronavirus? Maybe you can help spot a wildfire.
item.content:encoded: Stuck at home because of the coronavirus? Maybe you can help spot a wildfire.

media:content.media:description: A photo from one of Southern California Edison's publicly viewable live feed cameras covering its territory most vulnerable to wildfires.

item.title: South Coast Plaza launches curbside pickup
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: More than 80 stores and restaurants at the shopping center, which has been almost entirely shuttered since March 16, will participate.
item.content:encoded: More than 80 stores and restaurants at the shopping center, which has been almost entirely shuttered since March 16, will participate.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA. NOV. 20, 2012: Chinese exchange students(l to r)Dean Gao, Ross Liu and Lucas Xu stepping out of the Gucci store in South Coast Plaza on Nov. 20, 2012. The trio are Chinese exchange students at University of Colorado visiting Orange County during Thanksgiving break. South Coast Plaza in Costa Mesa is THE destination for foreign Asians shoppers. (Photo By Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: California coronavirus cases top 75,000, and nearly half are in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Luke Money, Patrick McGreevy, Priscella Vega
item.description: California surpasses 75,000 coronavirus cases Friday as officials continue to ease stay-at-home restrictions.
item.content:encoded: California surpasses 75,000 coronavirus cases Friday as officials continue to ease stay-at-home restrictions.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA-MAY 14, 2020: Background left to right-Friends Joshua Andrew, 32, of Chicago, Illinois, Bryan Hawn, 32, and Vlad Parker, 29, both of Santa Monica, wear masks to protect against the coronavirus while walking with others doing the same along the boardwalk in Venice Beach. A new rule, announced by Mayor Eric Garcetti on Wednesday, now requires face masks for all outdoor activities. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tracing coronavirus origins is vital to moving forward. But there's a catch — several, actually
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John, Annette Choi
item.description: To reopen safely amid coronavirus, experts need to trace the disease's origins. But bureaucratic roadblocks and other delays are getting in the way.
item.content:encoded: To reopen safely amid coronavirus, experts need to trace the disease's origins. But bureaucratic roadblocks and other delays are getting in the way.

media:content.media:description: SAN JOSE, CA -- MAY 08: Darryl Ospring, 67, at her home on Friday, May 8, 2020, in San Jose, CA. Among those now who wish their loved ones were tested for coronavirus is Ospring, whose mother, Marjorie Waggoner, 98, died Jan. 22. It started with feeling tired. Then a cough, fever, and in 10 days, death. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Why are Orange County coronavirus cases rising? Here's what we know
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Luke Money
item.description: The county has reported nearly 4,000 cases and 80 deaths and recorded its highest daily increase Thursday.
item.content:encoded: The county has reported nearly 4,000 cases and 80 deaths and recorded its highest daily increase Thursday.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE, CA -- TUESDAY, MAY 5, 2020: Armando Mendoza, 53, of Anaheim, who was the hospital's second-ever COVID-19 patient, spent 45 days at St. Joseph Hospital, the longest local stint of any COVID-19 patients, holds his wife, Lilia Mendoza's hand, and greeted by this mother, Evangelina Mendoza, center, and son, David Mendoza, right, as he is released to his awaiting family with applause and salutes from hospital workers in Orange, CA, on May 5, 2020. Mendoza was healthy and had no underlying health conditions when he contracted the virus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 5 kids found inside crate in back of pickup with no water, ventilation in 100-degree heat
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Three adults are arrested in Needles after deputies find five children, ages 1 to 13, inside a wooden box in the truck bed.
item.content:encoded: Three adults are arrested in Needles after deputies find five children, ages 1 to 13, inside a wooden box in the truck bed.

media:content.media:description: Three Sacramento residents were arrested in Needles this week after authorities allegedly found five small children riding in a makeshift crate in the back of their pickup truck.

item.title: Where do I need to wear a mask? The rules vary across Southern California
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa, Kailyn Brown, Luke Money, Kiera Feldman
item.description: Masks are required outdoors in Los Angeles city and county, but the rules are different in Orange County, Riverside County and elsewhere.
item.content:encoded: Masks are required outdoors in Los Angeles city and county, but the rules are different in Orange County, Riverside County and elsewhere.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - MAY 12: Masked visitors attend the re-opening of the Farmer's Market, in Manhattan Beach, CA, after being closed for eight weeks, Tuesday, May 12, 2020, during the coronavirus pandemic. There were 13 of the core farmers and two pre-packaged vendors, one with seafood and one baker, providing no-touch service. There was one-way traffic, with markings on the ground to help maintain social distancing, face coverings required and only 35 people allowed into the area at once. According to Manhattan Beach Farmer's Market Operator Cynthia Rogers, more vendors will be added each week, as the South Bay opens more business and services, but having the usual 50 vendors and open cooking is a long ways off. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Thunderbirds put on spectacular shows with flyover to support hospital workers, first responders
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Thunderbirds will fly over parts of Southern California today to honor workers on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The Thunderbirds will fly over parts of Southern California today to honor workers on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 15: Thunderbirds flyover downtown Los Angeles on Friday, May 15, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Face masks are now a mandatory L.A. accessory. Can we keep covered up?

item.description: L.A. now has strictest face mask requirements in California. Can we cover up?
item.content:encoded: L.A. now has strictest face mask requirements in California. Can we cover up?

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA-MAY 14, 2020: People wear masks to protect against the coronavirus while walking along the boardwalk in Venice Beach. A new rule, announced by Mayor Eric Garcetti on Wednesday, now requires face masks for all outdoor activities. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California schools face 'devastating' coronavirus cuts as they struggle to reopen
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Nina Agrawal
item.description: The coronavirus recession leads to California budget plan with major cuts to education.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus recession leads to California budget plan with major cuts to education.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, May 14, 2020. Reflecting the financial hit California is already seeing from the coronavirus, Newsom proposed cutting $6.1 billion from a variety programs in a state budget he says prioritizes public education, public health and public safety. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: LAPD officers shoot and kill man with handgun in Harbor Gateway
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Officers were called to a home on 123rd Street in the Harbor Gateway area by a report of a family dispute that became a call of a shooting in progress, police said.
item.content:encoded: Officers were called to a home on 123rd Street in the Harbor Gateway area by a report of a family dispute that became a call of a shooting in progress, police said.

item.content:encoded: The California Highway Patrol says a suspected drunk driver has crashed an SUV in San Jose, killing four passengers.

item.title: Coronavirus threatened their spring musical. But theater students say the show must go on
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: From Zoom practices to at-home recordings, the Orange County School of the Arts is performing its spring musical entirely online.
item.content:encoded: From Zoom practices to at-home recordings, the Orange County School of the Arts is performing its spring musical entirely online.

media:content.media:description: Musical theatre students at the Orange County School of the Arts took their performance online after their spring musical "Now. Here. This." was cancelled because of the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus leads to L.A. County Fair cancellation. It's the first time since WWII
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Live most other regional fairs and large gatherings, the Los Angeles County Fair won't happen as scheduled in September.
item.content:encoded: Live most other regional fairs and large gatherings, the Los Angeles County Fair won't happen as scheduled in September.

item.content:encoded: An outbreak at the LAPD training center has seen 17 trainee officers and jailers infected with the coronavirus, and officials are now implementing weekly testing.

After over 40 years at the LAPD, Earl Paysinger, the highest-ranking black officer who is about to retire. (Patrick T. Fallon/ For The Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Nearly a third of California counties have contained coronavirus enough to allow more reopenings
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California reopening: Nearly a third of counties have contained coronavirus enough to allow fewer restrictions.
item.content:encoded: California reopening: Nearly a third of counties have contained coronavirus enough to allow fewer restrictions.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, May 14, 2020. California Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom presented a revised $203 billion budget proposal to state lawmakers Thursday, reflecting an economy and tax revenues hobbled by the coronavirus pandemic. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Coachella and Cathedral City vote to mandate face coverings
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Coachella and Cathedral City officials voted to require the use of face masks in certain public settings.
item.content:encoded: Coachella and Cathedral City officials voted to require the use of face masks in certain public settings.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 5, 2020: Protesters enter the County Administrative Center to speak and listen during the Riverside County Board of Supervisors meeting in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 5, 2020 in Riverside, California. The protesters, many of them wearing apparel supporting Trump 2020, want the supervisors to rescind the public health orders.(Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California faces 'jaw dropping' unemployment, requiring more federal loans, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: At a news conference Thursday to present a revised state budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, Newsom said the state will need $43.8 billion to cover unemployment claims fueled by the coronavirus crisis in the new year, a 650% increase over what was originally proposed.
item.content:encoded: At a news conference Thursday to present a revised state budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, Newsom said the state will need $43.8 billion to cover unemployment claims fueled by the coronavirus crisis in the new year, a 650% increase over what was originally proposed.

media:content.media:description: CANOGA PARK, CA - MAY 14: Maria Mora came to find information about her claim but found the California State Employment Development Department was closed due to coronavirus concerns on Thursday, May 14, 2020 in Canoga Park, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Mass unemployment over coronavirus could lead to a 45% jump in homelessness, study finds
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: With the coronavirus-induced shock to the economy leaving millions out of work, homelessness in the U.S. could grow by 45% in a year, a study finds.
item.content:encoded: With the coronavirus-induced shock to the economy leaving millions out of work, homelessness in the U.S. could grow by 45% in a year, a study finds.

media:content.media:description: ECHO PARK, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 2020: Tyrone Dixon, 53, center, arrives with fellow homeless people from Skid Row via bus at the Echo Park Community Center, one of 13 Los Angeles area recreation centers that has become temporary shelters for homeless due to the growing coronavirus pandemic in Echo Park, Calif., on March 20, 2020. The homeless persons were awaiting beds to be set up before they could enter. The city of Los Angeles on Thursday released the locations of 13 recreation centers that will become temporary shelters for homeless people as the coronavirus pandemic continues to grow. The shelters will open Friday, and the city's Department of Recreation and Parks is preparing gymnasiums, finalizing 24-hour schedules for employees and ordering supplies. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California high court won't stop transfer of inmates to ICE during coronavirus crisis

item.description: California Supreme Court refuses to impose a moratorium on the transfer of immigrant inmates to ICE during the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: California Supreme Court refuses to impose a moratorium on the transfer of immigrant inmates to ICE during the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: 'Alarming increase': L.A. traffic deaths surge back to pre-pandemic levels
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Reduced traffic because of the coronavirus has led to more people speeding, more people walking around — and more traffic fatalities, L.A. police say.
item.content:encoded: Reduced traffic because of the coronavirus has led to more people speeding, more people walking around — and more traffic fatalities, L.A. police say.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 17, 2019 - New crosswalk at 94th and Figueroa as L.A. struggles to reduce fatal traffic crashes on city streets. The city has added new infrastructure -- more visible crosswalks, flashing lights at crosswalks, digital signs that show drivers their speed -- to help protect pedestrians and bicyclists. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus forces sharp cuts to schools, healthcare in California, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: California faces a $9.7-billion drop in tax revenues for the fiscal year that ends in June, with a total projected deficit of $54.3 billion through the early summer of 2021.
item.content:encoded: California faces a $9.7-billion drop in tax revenues for the fiscal year that ends in June, with a total projected deficit of $54.3 billion through the early summer of 2021.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, May 14, 2020. Reflecting the financial hit California is already seeing from the coronavirus, Newsom proposed cutting $6.1 billion from a variety of programs in a state budget he says prioritizes public education, public health and public safety. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Orange County reports its highest daily coronavirus case count
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Orange County confirmed 229 additional coronavirus cases Thursday, the highest number reported since the beginning of the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Orange County confirmed 229 additional coronavirus cases Thursday, the highest number reported since the beginning of the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE, CA -- TUESDAY, APRIL 14, 2020: UC Irvine Medical Center health care workers bang on the windows in a return of gratitude as they watch about 25 Orange County first responders vehicles participate in a drive-by parade of gratitude as they battle COVID-19 at the hospital, which currently has 8 patients with the virus in Orange, CA, on April 14, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County mandates masks outside as coronavirus deaths top 3,000 in California
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Sonja Sharp, Patrick McGreevy
item.description: As California's coronavirus case count approaches 75,000, 20 counties have met conditions to reopen more fully, the state said.
item.content:encoded: As California's coronavirus case count approaches 75,000, 20 counties have met conditions to reopen more fully, the state said.

media:content.media:description: NEWHALL, CA-MAY 13, 2020: Carlos Marroquin, 53, left, owner of Planet Soccer, shows his appreciation to customers Benton Watkins, 13, and his mother Noelle,47, of Santa Clarita, after she purchased a soccer ball, soccer cleats and shin guards for he son at the store in Newhall that re-opened. All are wearing protective covering against the coronavirus. Noelle and Benton have been customers since he was 8 years old. Marroquin has owned the store for the past 16 years and during that time, he has provided gear but more importantly, support and advice to AYSO leagues, high school teams and weekend warriors in the Santa Clarita Valley. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Bernardino County reports another 18 coronavirus deaths, biggest daily increase in fatalities

Seated from left are Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, Sen. Mike Braun, R-Ind., center, and Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky. (Win McNamee/Pool via AP)

item.title: L.A. now requires face coverings even when outside. Here are the rules
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp, Hannah Fry
item.description: The significant increase in the city's coronavirus mandates is necessary to help slow the spread of COVID-19, Mayor Eric Garcetti says.
item.content:encoded: The significant increase in the city's coronavirus mandates is necessary to help slow the spread of COVID-19, Mayor Eric Garcetti says.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 11: Yiran Zou, a student at the California College of Art in San Francisco prepares to fly home to China at Tom Bradley International Terminal, Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) which is now requiring travelers to wear face covering to help keep fellow passengers and crew safe by limiting the spread of the coronavirus Covid-19. The new requirements for wearing face masks in Los Angels began Monday at LAX and on local public transit. LAX on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. requires face coverings outdoors to slow coronavirus, help lift stay-at-home restrictions
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Susanne Rust, Sonja Sharp
item.description: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti announced Wednesday evening that all Angelenos, except for small children and those with certain disabilities, would be required to wear face coverings outside.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti announced Wednesday evening that all Angelenos, except for small children and those with certain disabilities, would be required to wear face coverings outside.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA-MAY 6, 2020: Caroline Kousidonis, 52, of Venice, wears a protective mask against the coronavirus while walking past a mural on Lincoln Blvd. in Venice. She is a producer for television commercials and said that her work has been reduced by over 90% because of the coronavirus. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: News Analysis: California's $54-billion deficit fueled by coronavirus will test a decade of preparations
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom will offer the Legislature his ideas Thursday on how to eliminate a deficit fueled by the coronavirus crisis that could total $54.3 billion between now and July of next year.
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom will offer the Legislature his ideas Thursday on how to eliminate a deficit fueled by the coronavirus crisis that could total $54.3 billion between now and July of next year.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom presents his first state budget during a news conference, Thursday, Jan. 10, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom's new budget is a figure that says a lot about California's shaky legal marijuana market: the state is expecting a lot less cash coming in from cannabis taxes. The Democrat's proposed spending plan projects the state will bank $355 million in marijuana excise taxes by the end of June, roughly half of what was once expected after broad legal sales kicked off last year. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: LAPD arrests Santa Monica woman, seizes 61 unapproved coronavirus test kits

item.title: California community colleges sue U.S. for denying COVID-19 funds to undocumented students, others
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: The nation's largest community college system filed a lawsuit this week over the use of federal coronavirus relief funds.
item.content:encoded: The nation's largest community college system filed a lawsuit this week over the use of federal coronavirus relief funds.

media:content.media:description: In this Sept. 17, 2018 photo, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos speaks during a student town hall at National Constitution Center in Philadelphia. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is proposing a major overhaul to the way colleges handle complaints of sexual misconduct. The Education Department released a plan Friday that would require schools to investigate sexual assault and harassment only if it was reported to certain campus officials and only if it occurred on campus or other areas overseen by the school. (AP Photo/Matt Rourke)

item.title: Republicans stake congressional victory, claim seat Democrat Katie Hill vacated
item.dc:creator: Mark Z. Barabak, Arit John
item.description: Republicans say the win in California bodes well for November. Others aren't so sure.
item.content:encoded: Republicans say the win in California bodes well for November. Others aren't so sure.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Jan. 28, 2020 file photo, 25th District congressional candidate and former Navy combat pilot Mike Garcia greets supporters in Simi Valley, Calif. The fight for an open U.S. House seat in a swing district north of Los Angeles provides Republicans with a rare opportunity to gain ground in heavily Democratic California, and the outcome could send a message about where voters place their trust during the coronavirus crisis. The toss-up contest between Republican Garcia and Democrat Christy Smith will inevitably be seen as a proxy vote on President Donald Trump's leadership during the crisis. (AP Photo/Michael Blood,File)

item.title: Newsom promises new wildfire prevention efforts during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, John Myers

item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday that California is preparing for a particularly tough fire season as it continues its efforts to slow the spread of coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: FILE - This April 9, 2020, file photo shows California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaking at a news briefing at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. California will help skilled nursing facilities wracked by the new virus by providing additional bed space for their patients on a Navy hospital ship and shipping masks and gloves for their workers, the governor said Friday, April 10. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

"This is our favorite restaurant in town," said Ruslan. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

The practice day drew thousands of spectators lining the sands to see stunt planes belching smoke and the USAF Thunderbirds flying over a large swath of Huntington Beach along the coast from Seapoint to Beach Boulevard Mark Boster/For The Los Angeles Times

item.title: The two big reasons why California is struggling to control coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: Health officials say the coronavirus crisis persists because some people must still go out and because others are fed up with the stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: Health officials say the coronavirus crisis persists because some people must still go out and because others are fed up with the stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - MAY 11, 2020 - - Bikers, against a backdrop of the Queen Mary, make their way along pedestrian and beach bike path on the first day that Long Beach reopened the path on Monday May 11, 2020. The city of Long Beach eased a few of its public health restrictions, allowing under certain guidelines the reopening of pedestrian and beach bike paths, tennis centers and courts. Beach bathrooms are also reopening, but the parking lots and beaches still remain closed. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: YUBA CITY, CA -- MAY 06: Customers wait in line on a first come first serve basis to have body piercings at Heart & Soul Tattoo on Wednesday, May 6, 2020, in Yuba City, CA. Every 30 minutes Wagner must stop and desensitize the table. The shop closes at 3 P.M. for an hour to sanitize the space. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus is stalling air quality, pollution rules, even in eco-minded California
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: Powerful industries are pressuring California regulators to delay or roll back air quality and climate regulations due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Powerful industries are pressuring California regulators to delay or roll back air quality and climate regulations due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: WILMINGTON, CA -- TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 2016 -- The Phillips 66 refinery looms over a Wilmington neighborhood where some long-time residents feel their health issues might stem from their proximity to the refinery. The Union Oil Company of California built the original refinery in 1919 between the old Anaheim road and the port, years before homes were constructed to form the neighborhood. ( Rick Loomis / Los Angeles Times )

item.title: S. David Freeman, public power chief and energy advisor, dies at 94
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: S. David Freeman, who led the nation's largest public utilities including the LADWP with a commanding and at times uncompromising vision, dies at 94.
item.content:encoded: S. David Freeman, who led the nation's largest public utilities including the LADWP with a commanding and at times uncompromising vision, dies at 94.

media:content.media:description: L.A. LEADERS: Geraldine Knatz, left, the L.A. port's executive director, and S. David Freeman, L.A. harbor commission president.

item.title: Most California voters say coronavirus is increasing inequality, especially among blacks, poll finds
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: Some 70% of California voters believe that the COVID-19 pandemic is increasing inequality in the United States, according to a UC Berkeley IGS poll. Most also agreed that there were racial disparities in the virus' effect.
item.content:encoded: Some 70% of California voters believe that the COVID-19 pandemic is increasing inequality in the United States, according to a UC Berkeley IGS poll. Most also agreed that there were racial disparities in the virus' effect.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-APRIL 8, 2020: A portrait and quote by Martin Luther King, Jr. overlooks a new mobile testing site for people with symptoms of the coronavirus at Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on Wednesday, April 8, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: They're trapped, and the killer virus knows where to find them in California
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: COVID-19 doesn't play fair. It goes after the institutionalized, the poor and the elderly.
item.content:encoded: COVID-19 doesn't play fair. It goes after the institutionalized, the poor and the elderly.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA -- TUESDAY, MAY 12, 2020: Rep. Nanette Diaz Barragan speaks during a press conference after touring the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island site to inquire about the ``extremely high'' number of COVID-19 cases among inmates and prison staff and about the steps being taken to address them. Photo taken outside the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island gate in San Pedro, CA, on May 12, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: A patient's return to hospital COVID-19 unit underscores uncertainty to come
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Janice Brown was the first patient at Desert Valley Hospital's COVID-19 unit. And the first to be released. Neither she nor her doctors or nurses expected her to return. Within weeks, she tested positive again.
item.content:encoded: Janice Brown was the first patient at Desert Valley Hospital's COVID-19 unit. And the first to be released. Neither she nor her doctors or nurses expected her to return. Within weeks, she tested positive again.

media:content.media:description: VICTORVILLE, CA - APRIL 29: Janice Brown, left, grimaces, as dialysis nurse Jennifer Stolpp pokes her arm for dialysis at Desert Valley Medical Group. Victorville, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Democrat Christy Smith concedes to Republican Mike Garcia in election to fill Katie Hill's seat
item.dc:creator: Arit John
item.description: California Republicans hadn't won control of a Democratic-held congressional seat since 1998.
item.content:encoded: California Republicans hadn't won control of a Democratic-held congressional seat since 1998.

media:content.media:description: Republican Mike Garcia and Democrat Christy Smith are locked in a congressional race that both sides rate a toss-up.

item.title: After seventh coronavirus death at Terminal Island, congresswoman says inmates lack protection
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: After a seventh inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison died, a U.S. congresswoman visited and said detainees were desperate for protective equipment.
item.content:encoded: After a seventh inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison died, a U.S. congresswoman visited and said detainees were desperate for protective equipment.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA -- TUESDAY, MAY 12, 2020: Rep. Nanette Diaz Barragan puts a mask on that she was given while speaking during a press conference after touring the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island site to inquire about the ``extremely high'' number of COVID-19 cases among inmates and prison staff and about the steps being taken to address them. Photo taken outside the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island gate in San Pedro, CA, on May 12, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 60 businesses charged with violating stay-at-home rules
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The owners of 60 businesses across L.A. are now facing criminal charges for violating Mayor Garcetti's stay-at-home order.
item.content:encoded: The owners of 60 businesses across L.A. are now facing criminal charges for violating Mayor Garcetti's stay-at-home order.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Atty. Mike Feuer speaks Aug. 31, 2017.

item.title: Earthquake: 3.2 quake shakes near Palm Springs
item.description: A magnitude 3.2 earthquake was reported Tuesday evening at 6:31 p.m.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.2 earthquake was reported Tuesday evening at 6:31 p.m.

item.title: New signs that coronavirus restrictions are here for the long haul in California
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy, Colleen Shalby, Nina Agrawal
item.description: Even as officials laid out more tentative plans to reopen California's battered economy, there were growing signs Tuesday that life would not be getting back to normal any time soon.
item.content:encoded: Even as officials laid out more tentative plans to reopen California's battered economy, there were growing signs Tuesday that life would not be getting back to normal any time soon.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - MAY 12: Kim Abt, left, and Rachel Portugal walk the beach after a social media workout Tuesday morning on the sand in Santa Monica as Los Angeles County Beaches will reopen tomorrow for active use only due to the coronavirus pandemic. Parking lots, piers and boardwalks will remain closed. Beach on Tuesday, May 12, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man whose wife and daughter died in crash that killed Kobe Bryant sues helicopter owner
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Christopher Chester, whose wife and daughter died in the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, has sued the company that operated the helicopter and the estate of the deceased pilot.
item.content:encoded: Christopher Chester, whose wife and daughter died in the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, has sued the company that operated the helicopter and the estate of the deceased pilot.

media:content.media:description: The crash site of the helecopter Kobe Bryant was believed to be in on Sunday, Jan 26, 2020 in Calabasas.

item.title: Silicon Valley has no plans now to weaken coronavirus stay-at-home order
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Silicon Valley has no immediate plans to weaken coronavirus stay-at-home order
item.content:encoded: Silicon Valley has no immediate plans to weaken coronavirus stay-at-home order

media:content.media:description: Santa Clara County Public Health Department Director Dr. Sara Cody speaks during a news conference in San Jose, Calif., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. Santa Clara County health officials confirmed a second case of unknown origin of the novel coronavirus. (Anda Chu/Bay Area News Group via AP)

item.title: Orange County will unveil proposed coronavirus 'reopening' guidelines this week
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Orange County supervisors, and dozens of residents who turned out to lobby them this week, are increasingly itching to relax restrictions that were imposed in response to the coronavirus outbreak and reopen businesses and public spaces.
item.content:encoded: Orange County supervisors, and dozens of residents who turned out to lobby them this week, are increasingly itching to relax restrictions that were imposed in response to the coronavirus outbreak and reopen businesses and public spaces.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE COUNTY, CA - MAY 11: People walk at Seal Beach on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Orange County, CA. Seal Beach reopened to active use on Monday and will only be open during daylight hours Monday through Thursday. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD shootings hit 30-year low in 2019; less-lethal force has increased
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Fatal shootings by L.A. police officers declined for the fourth year in a row, according to a new report on police use of force.
item.content:encoded: Fatal shootings by L.A. police officers declined for the fourth year in a row, according to a new report on police use of force.

media:content.media:description: LAPD officers at a protest near City Hall on Tuesday, July 12.

item.title: Newsom sets new rules for reopening California restaurants, malls and offices amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Two months after Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at home order began, restaurants can reopen in counties meeting standards tied to the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Two months after Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at home order began, restaurants can reopen in counties meeting standards tied to the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)
